NewsLine.NewsLineText: WORLD NEWS SCHEDULE AT 1000 GMT:SCHEDULE-World News at 1000 GMT

body.p: Following are the main news stories due in the next few hours or moved earlier (all times GMT):
GERMAN ELECTION
BERLIN - Germany faces continued economic stagnation after Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder wins re-election with a reduced majority that narrows his scope to implement painful reforms.
(GERMANY (UPDATE 2), BY DAVID CROSSLAND, MOVING SHORTLY, PICTURE, GRAPHIC)

BERLIN - German Chancellor Schroeder, whose strident opposition to any U.S. war with Iraq helped him win a slim new mandate, will hurry to patch up ties with Washington but he cannot make a complete about-face to win back favour.
(GERMANY-RELATIONS, BY EMMA THOMASSON, EXPECT BY 1230)
SEE ALSO:
GERMANY-GREENS BY PHILIP BLENKINSOP, EXPECT BY 1400
GERMANY-CONSERVATIVES, BY CLIFFORD COONAN, EXPECT BY 1430, PICTURE
EU-GERMANY-EAST, BY DOUGLAS BUSVINE, EXPECT BY 1400
GERMANY-REACTION, EXPECT BY 1200
GERMANY-ELECTION-STOCKS, BY MARIUS BOSCH, EXPECT BY 1130
ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN CONFLICT
RAMALLAH, West Bank - Israeli troops press on with siege of Yasser Arafat's West Bank headquarters after halting demolition of his presidential complex following U.S. criticism.
(MIDEAST (UPDATE 3), BY WAFA AMR, EXPECT BY 1330, PICTURE)
DAMASCUS - Syria calls on United Nations to rein in Israel and its military action against Palestinians, saying that conflict deserved as much attention as global body is giving to Iraq.
(MIDEAST-SYRIA-OMRAN (INTERVIEW), BY SAMIA NAKHOUL, MOVING SHOTRLY)
IVORY COAST TURMOIL

YAMOUSSOUKRO - French troops sent to help trapped Westerners set up camp on road to Ivory Coast's second city, where dozens of American children are among foreigners trapped by a bloody military uprising.
(IVORYCOAST (UPDATE 2), BY EMMANUEL BRAUN, EXPECT BY 1300)
NORTH KOREA
COPENHAGEN - South Korean President Kim Dae-jung tells European Union and Asian leaders North Korea's overtures to its neighbours point to eventual reunification of peninsula.
(EU-ASIA-SUMMIT, (UPDATE 1), BY GARETH JONES, EXPECT BY 1200)
SEE ALSO:
KOREA-NORTH-GAMES, (UPDATE 2), BY LEE JAE-WON, MOVED, PICTURE
KOREA-NORTH, BY PAUL ECKERT, MOVED, PICTURE
RUSSIA
MOSCOW - Rescuers evacuate residents of Caucasus valley from floodwaters rising dramatically after weekend Caucasus mudslide in which more than 100 people are missing and feared dead.
(RUSSIA-MUDSLIDE, BY OLIVER BULLOUGH, EXPECT BY 1230)
HURRICANE ISIDORE
MERIDA, Mexico - Hurricane Isidore ploughs across Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, forcing thousands from their homes as it floods streets, topples trees and power lines and shuts down offshore oil rigs.
(WEATHER-ISIDORE (UPDATE 1), BY PABLO GARIIBIAN, PICTURE, EXPECT BY 1200)
AFGHANISTAN

HERAT, Afghanistan - The powerful governor of Afghanistan's Herat province says Taliban and al Qaeda remnants still pose a serious threat to security and cites the recent attempt on the life of the president as an example.
(AFGHAN-ALQAEDA-HERAT, BY MIKE COLLETT-WHITE, MOVED)
AFRICA
GOMA, Congo - Rwanda's pull-out from Congo risks enflaming an already desperate humanitarian crisis as armed groups battle for control in the resulting power vacuum, aid workers say.
(CONGO-DEMOCRATIC-HUNGER, BY MATTHEW GREEN, EXPECT BY 1500, PICTURE)
HARARE - Zimbabwe launches a blistering attack on Australian Prime Minister John Howard, accusing him of racism and treating Africans in the same way Australia treats Aborigines.
(ZIMBABWE-COMMONWEALTH-AUSTRALIA, MOVED)
EMMY AWARDS
LOS ANGELES - The prime-time Emmy Awards prove again that no one should ever underestimate the power of the U.S. presidency, at least on television.
(LEISURE-EMMYS, BY STEVE GORMAN, MOVING SHORTLY, PICTURE)

WASHINGTON NEWSDESK: +1 202-898-8465
